author: Special Correspondent
text:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi placed before an audience of Ayurveda experts and students here on Tuesday the benefits of preventive and curative health care from Indian systems of medicine and also an economic spin-off in the form of national and international market for skills and products. At the same time, he stressed the need to address concerns over quality standards at a time when Ayurveda and the others systems of alternative or complementary medicine were gaining global acceptance.

Addressing a Vision Conclave of the Global Ayurveda Festival, organised by various organisations in this field of medicine, the Prime Minister said the country needed health-care systems that could lower the burden of non-communicable and lifestyle-related diseases. The Centre was focussed on tapping the potential of holistic medicine not only as an efficacious system of treatment, but also as a viable economic activity.

“One must also ponder over the challenges. Traditional medicine is what our rural sections get to have in health care. In this context, affordability, quality, and rational use must get prime focus,” he said.

Chief Minister Oommen Chandy requested Mr. Modi that the international standards Ayurveda research institute planned by the Centre be established in Kerala.

Stresses on need to maintain quality of health-care system
title: Need to lower burden of lifestyle-related diseases: PM
